awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Analyzing Customer Behavior for Energy Usage Moderation
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the potential development of an optimization algorithm that could identify energy consumption patterns that may enable moderation and management of electricity consumption. This technology could help in infrastructure planning, enhance customer relations by understanding the customer's energy behavior, and provide individualized or customized feedback to avoid circuit overload, power quality issues, and power outages (blackouts) which are major problems for the electricity utility and microgrid companies. There is an unmet need to understand customer energy behavior patterns in different geographies and demographics to help create informed decision-making on infrastructure planning and deployment. In addition to application in electricity utility companies, this technology can potentially be adapted for deployment in other applications that require utility infrastructure planning and consumer behavior change, such as gas and water distribution.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a proprietary automatic multi-parametric optimization and machine learning clustering algorithm that could forecast upcoming load on the electrical grid. This is done by analyzing overall and personalized energy consumption by consumers based on variables reflecting localized geography, weather conditions, seasonal conditions (winter vs summer), and time and day electricity consumption as well as demographics. Using multi-parametric variables, a regularization-based optimization algorithm is developed that decouples the contribution of each influencing factor in load consumption to avoid circuit overload and power quality issues. To avoid blackouts, the output of the multi-parametric optimization is combined with a proprietary machine-learning clustering technique that analyzes the load consumption behavior/ pattern in different demographics and maps behavior with the population density to improve load forecast for better accuracy to avoid power outages. The combination of multi-parametric optimization and clustering helps to identify customer load patterns and hence could help in identifying highly accurate load forecast for load balancing which will eliminate blackouts in a region.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Electricity transmission and distribution is over a trillion-dollar market in the United States, with companies in the NY State alone generating revenues of $22 billion per year, which is growing at 1.7% per annum.  According to market research reports, blackouts costs electricity companies between $137 million (e.g. Con-Ed) to $10 billion (e.g., Pacific Gas & Electric, San Diego Gas and Electric), depending on their market capitalization. For small microgrid companies (Take Solar Corporation, Carnegie Clean Energy), the blackout fines are an existential threat that can lead to bankruptcy. The higher energy prices and blackouts are increasingly becoming common due to limited supply of electricity, as communities are transitioning to green energy sources. Many solutions focus on energy storage and battery deployment; however, community-focus consumption moderation is most effective way to address the problem. It reduces overall electricity consumption, increase the share of green energy and moderates the electricity prices. Our optimization algorithms identify the consumption patterns that enables the moderation and management of electricity consumption. This technology will help in infrastructure planning, enhancing customer relations by understanding their customer's energy behavior, and providing individualized or customized feedback for their energy savings.

In grids, infrastructure deployment directly trade-offs with the blackout reduction. Higher the infrastructure development less the blackouts and vice-versa. We provide a novel targeted flexible load shifting approach from peak to non-peak period that reduces the infrastructure expansion and the blackouts at the same time, similar to what would have been obtained after the infrastructure expansion. Our algorithm activates the load shifting. Moreover, electricity price is exponentially proportional to the grid load in peak hours, therefore, shifting load to non-peak time of the day will reduce electricity price which results in saving consumers electricity bill and provide benefit to the community. There are two novel features of our approach: 1) Ability to identify similarity in electricity usage variation pattern at any time of the day. 2) Identify flexible loads which have ability to be shifted to non-peak periods.

The potential of our technology to avoid circuit overload, power quality issues and power outages (blackouts), which is a major problem for the electricity utility companies, as it costs millions to billions of dollars in fines. There is an unmet need to understand customer energy behavior patterns in different geography and demography, as it is essential for informed decision making on infrastructure planning and deployment; under capacity leads to blackouts and overcapacity lead to high maintenance costs. Our technology can be leveraged to help moderate and redistribute the electricity consumption, based on the renewal energy generation, reducing the carbon footprint.
